lines.content: # User Guide for Duke - A Command-Line Interface (CLI) Task Manager

Duke is a Personal Assistant Chatbot in the form of a CLI programme that helps users keep track of various types of tasks. Duke is useful for fast typists who can manage their tasks quickly using Duke as compared to traditional Graphical User Interface (GUI) apps.
1. Ensure you have Java 11 installed in your Computer.
3. Copy the file to the folder you would like to use as the *home folder* for Duke
4. Double-click the file. Your terminal or command prompt should open up.
5. Type `java -jar ip.jar` and press Enter to start the app.
6. Type any command in the Features section below and press Enter to execute it.
Shows a list of all the tasks you have in your list.
Adds a Todo to the task list. A Todo is a task with only a description.
Adds an event to the task list. An event is a task with a description and a time of occurrence.
Adds a deadline to the task list. A deadline is a task with a description and a due time.
Deletes a task from the task list based on its index in the list. You can use the `list` command first if you are unaware of the specific index to use.
Marks a task, selected via its index, as complete. An 'X' will appear beside the task when using the `list` command
Marks a task, selected via its index, as incomeplete. There will be no 'X' beside the task when using the `list` command
Lists out all relevant tasks based on a search term, along with their status.
Duke data are saved in the hard disk automatically after any command changes the data. There is no need to save manually.
* Creates an instance of Duke Programme, with data available in file path.
* Based on storage created through the file path, an error message would be shown if the file does not exist
* @param filePath the file path of the text document that would be used for reading and writing
* Runs the instance of Duke Programme.
* This is the main method which creates a new Duke instance to be run.
* Looks out for output using a Scanner object and carries the conversation with the user.
* Based on the first input of the user, this method will check if it is exactly "bye",
* which is the exit command for this programme.
* If it is not, it will try to interpret the command through a runCommand() method.
* This method will continue a while loop so long as the user does not give an input "bye".
System.out.println("☹ OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(");
System.out.println("☹ OOPS!!! Description cannot be empty!");
* Creates an instance of Parser that is used to interpret commands.
* @param ui      the Ui object used for this particular instance.
* @param tasks   the TaskList object for this instance.
* @param storage the Storage object for this instance.
public Parser(Ui ui, TaskList tasks, Storage storage) {
* This method is used to interpret every input given by the user as a command.
* Based on the input given by the user, another method will be called to carry out

*
  • listing out all tasks with their statuses and details

*
  • finding tasks based on a search term
* @param response input given by the user.
* @param storage Storage object for this instance of Duke.
public void runCommand(String response, TaskList tasks, Storage storage) throws UnknownCommandException {
* This method lists out the task in the TaskList.
System.out.println("There are currently no tasks in your list!");
* This method adds a task to the TaskList, with interaction with the user.
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task:");
System.out.println("Now you have " + tasks.getSize() + " task(s) in the list.");
* This method adds a deadline to the TaskList. with interaction with the
* user as well as error handling.
* This method adds an event to the TaskList. with interaction with the
* user as well as error handling.
* This method marks a task as complete, with interaction with the user.
* @return a boolean variable indicating if there has been any update or not.
boolean isNotIndex = taskIndex > tasks.getSize() || taskIndex == 0 || taskIndex < 0;
System.out.println("Sorry, seems like there's no such task with that index.");
Task t = tasks.getTaskViaIndex(taskIndex - 1); //list indexing to the user starts from 1 but list indexing in fact starts from 0 internally
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
System.out.println("Hmm, you've already marked this task.");
System.out.println("☹ OOPS!!! You forgot to indicate an index!");
* Marks a task as incomplete with interaction with the user.
* @return boolean variable indicating if there has been any update.
System.out.println("Sorry, seems like there's no such task with that index.");
Task t = tasks.getTaskViaIndex(taskIndex - 1); //list indexing to the user starts from 1 but list indexing in fact starts from 0 internally
System.out.println("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:");
System.out.println("Hmm, this task is already unmarked.");
System.out.println("☹ OOPS!!! You forgot to indicate an index!");
* Deletes a task from TaskList with interaction with the user.
System.out.println("Sorry, seems like there's no such task with that index.");
System.out.println("Now you have " + tasks.getSize() + " tasks in the list");
System.out.println("☹ OOPS!!! You forgot to indicate an index!");
* Finds tasks based on search term and prints out the tasks that match
* Creates a new instance of Storage.
* The storage object stores the file path for future use of writing to it during the progranmme.
* @param filePath file path of text document used for data reading and writing.
* This method loads the data stored in the text document,
* using the file path stored in the storage object. If there is no such file,
* a new file will be created in the directory specified.
* @return the task list generated by the text document.
* @throws IOException if there is no file found.
* This method is used every time there is an update to the task list,
* be it addition, deletion, or change in status of the tasks.
* @param taskList the latest task list used to update the text document.
* Creates an instance of deadline object.
* Prints out the deadline in a custom format.
* converts the deadline into a string that is to be written back into
* @return String to be written back into storage.
* Prints out the event in a custom format.
* converts the event into a string that is to be written back into
* @return String to be written back into storage.
* Creates a task. This method is used for Todo objects.
* @throws NullPointerException when there is no description.
* This method checks the isDone attribute of the task.
* It will return the status of the task to be used for printing in various methods.
* @return status icon of the task in the form of a string.
return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done task with X
* @return boolean value indicating if the task in question is complete or not.
* Prints out the task in a custom format.
* converts the task into a string that is to be written back into
* @return String to be written back into storage.
* converts status of task into string to be written back into text document.
* @return String of status of task to be written back into storage.
* Prints out the todo in a custom format.
* converts the todo into a string that is to be written back into
* @return String to be written back into storage.
* Creates a TaskList object based on the ArrayList of Tasks provided.
* This ArrayList should be created with the data stored in the text document
* This constructor is used should there be no data available/
* the file indicated is not found. A new empty ArrayList storing Tasks will be created.
* @return the size of the taskArrayList attribute of this taskList.
* @param index the index of the task in the taskArrayList.
* @return the Task object that is of that index in the taskArrayList.
* This method adds a specific task to the taskArrayList.
* @param task the Task to be added.
* This method removes a specific task from the taskArrayList.
* @param task the Task to be removed.
* This method is used to filter tasks based on a search term.
* @param detail The search term used to compare with all tasks.
* @return An ArrayList of tasks that contain the search term.
* Starting of a programme by showing a welcome message and greeting the user.
* This is a method used to print a line for aesthetic purposes throughout the programme.
* This method shows an elaborate welcome message with a logo.
* This method gives a short greeting to the user.
System.out.println("What can I do for you?");
* This method is used when exiting the programme, to bid the user farewell.
System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
* This method is used when the file location given by the user does not exist.
* It will tell the user that the programme is creating a new file.
* @param filePath file path of the text document that would contain relevant data.
System.out.println(filePath + " file not found.\nnew file has been created");
